Not my first choice there, but a very decent beer.

Served slightly too cold in an imperial pint. Creamy looking head, the body is hazy orange. Smell is mild, light caramel, fruity malt, and floral hops. Taste is excellent, some malty fruitiness with a clean bitterness. Mouthfeel is smooth, low carbonation. Great drinkability.

Pours a cloudy, lighter copper color. Hints of orange as well. Thin white head disappears quick. Floral and citrusy hop aroma. Slight biscuity malt, followed by some citrusy hop flavor. Fair amount of bitterness. Low carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. Very, very easy to drink. Maybe a bit to citrusy for a bitter, but this was pretty good stuff on cask.

I was lucky enough to find this beer on cask at the brewpub, and got a pint and a growler. The beer is a clear light copper with a soapy white head. Aroma is a mix of toasted malt, bread, and some earthy and fruity notes. Flavor begins slightly sweet, with bread and buscuit notes. Has a light fruitiness to it... passion fruit comes to mind... then finishes with a light herbal bitterness. Mouthfeel is light and carbonation is low, as would be expected. This is a style that can be difficult to find... and it can be even more difficult to find a good beer in the style. This is a top notch example of a british bitter... it left my mouth watering for more.

Pale straw in color and cloudy. Not much head to speak of. A beer brewed for the "lite" crowd, light malt aroma/flavor, and lightly hopped (both in aroma and flavor). This beer finished on the dry and bitter side. A beer you could put a lot of away on a hot day.

The lawnmower pours a pale golden hue with little head. Vague sweet aromas overlayed by fresh grass. Attacks with mint and thyme, leading to a light lemon peel and lemongrass hop flavor. Crisp minerality and light in body makes it a treasure for a hot day.

Very nice PA! It had a very light and clear color to it, not even straw colored, which I thought was interesting. Good scent, nice and clean, with just a little bitterness. Very refreshing taste, not too bitter, a nice mix of malt and hops. Goes down very smoothly and is easy to drink.

This is a basic, well-done, conservative, consistently high-quality APA from the city's best brewpub. It's not a world-shaker, it's not something you'd drive from across the country to sample. It's not meant to be...BRBP has other beers for that. This is a fine beer, that's good every time I have it. It's also a great beer for people that aren't into craft brews. If you take a macro-drinker to dinner at the BRBP, suggest this to them for a starter. No, it's nothing to write home about, but it is a solid, tasty brew.

From a sampler: This beer is a clear gold color with a thin white head. Very little lacing. The aroma is Lager-ish. Light-bodied and mildy hoppy throughout, but not much else going on flavor-wise other than hints of malt here and there. The finish is kind of docile as well. I understand why the name, as this is an unexciting but drinkable beer.

Poured a wonderful deep dark black color with nice initial head and decent lacing. Wonderfully deep and dark roasted grain aroma with hints of coffee. Wonderful deep flavor with great roasted grains, and hints of chocolate and coffee. Very smooth and nicely dry going down. An excellent example of an Irish dry stout.

On cask at the brewpub. Pours dark and thick, deep dark ruby with a nice brown chocolate head. Maybe a little colder than I would have liked out of a cask stout, but whatever. Tasted and smelled like a run-of-the-mill, well-brewed dry stout. Malt profile leaned a little bit towards the dry chocolate side, with crumbled Oreos mixing with dry, burnt grain that was a little rougher in the aroma than in the flavor. The middle was creamy and the finish was a good dose of dry, potent hops that lingered long after the beer had been swallowed.

Enjoyed on cask at the Broad Ripple Brew Pub Smell, bitter, hint of nuts, coffee, and chocolate. Taste, big coffee notes with some nuts swimming along. I love the chocolate malt flavors going on in this one. Not too dry, but very crisp. Big flavors going on here, but with a medium body. Overall, a fantastic beer that I could drink all night. Man I wish I had a keg of this stuff.

Pours a nice deep brown/near black color with some nice initial (non-lasting) head. Scent is nearly covered up by the oak chips the beer aged on; some nice malt, but nothing else really stoutish comes through besides a very, very slight hint of coffee. Taste has a lot of oak barrel, a bit of roastiness, and just the slightest hint of coffee; for such a high ABV beer, it has a rather thin body. Goes down alright, but perhaps a bit to oaky; hints of alcohol; creamy but not as deep as it could be.

Excellent beer, it had a nice dark color, just a bit lighter than a brown ale, a nice deep amber. It had a nice deep smell, slightly hoppy. A great taste, very hoppy and a bit bitter, but it had a nice deep flavor to it. Goes down nice and is easy to drink.

Pours a fantastic black with decent head and lacing. Excellent deep roasted grain and coffee aromas. Great flavors, with roasted grains and great coffee flavors with a nice crisp malt sweetness; the flavors merged great as well. Went down extremely well.

This was the last beer I tried for the night at BRBP and we were headed to a beer tasting so my notes are very short. A: Dark, no head. S: Coffee T: Wonderful hints of chocolate and coffee. Bitter chocolate aftertaste. M: Smooth almost creamy with a perfectly balanced bitterness. D: I could drink a few.

race day drop by for my first experience here. deep brown/black and very opaque. no head whatsoever on the pour. yeasty and slightly rusty aroma. hints of burnt nuts is an afterthought. a superbly malty character, hinging between burnt malt and caramel malt. nutty as well, flavored almost like a typical dark lager very flat feel. watery as much as it is heavy. decent brew but leaves me wondering if they couldn't kick up the carbonation at all. very flavorful even if the other aspects aren't spectacular.

Draft sample at IBG Winterfest. A - Poured a hazy brown color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. S- Moderate Roasted and small hop aroma. T - Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. M - Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. D - This beer met my expectations.

Poured from 22 oz bomber into my NBB snifter. A: Pours a clear and deep claret with a hint of carbonation and sediment. Almost no head forms. S: Mild sour cherry, and soft oak notes. Faint hint of malt. T: Follows aroma well. Sour, sour cherry and apple. Soft oak and malt. M: Mouth-puckeringly sour. Light to medium body. Dry acidic finish. Good for style. D: This beer style is not for all people. From what I've seen it tends to polarize people--they love it or hate it. Personally, I love it. One of the best offerings from NBB. It seems to do best when paired with food.

The beer's coloring looks really nice - it's a dark red with absolutely nothing for a head. A very potent sourness and vinegar as you take a sniff, which is expected given it's a sour brown ale. Where I have a real problem with the beer is the taste. To be completely honest, the beer tastes like I drank some funky cough syrup, then upchucked a bit in mouth...but kept it in, so ended up tasting the stomach acid again on the way down. I can't just get past that. I took a few more sips and did get some more flavors - sour apple, sour cherry. The vinegar flavor comes up again in the aftertaste... I couldn't finish the whole bomber, which is sad given the price - $13 bucks! EPIC FAIL by New Belgium Appearance - 3.5/5.0 - A pretty dark red with nada for head Smell - 2.5/5.0 - Oy...vinegar and pungent sourness. Taste - 2.5/5.0 - GAG - sour, vinegar, cough syrup, stomach acid, with some sour apple & cherry after getting into the beer Feel - 1.5/5.0 - It certainly sticks with you... Drinkability - 1.0/5.0 - No way Jose. This is definitely an...acquired taste.

Split a 22 two ways. Reviewed 12/10/2009. Bottled 4/6/2009 Ar: Tart berries, dark sweet malt, lactic and acetic acids, raspberry, light cranberry, light toasty malt, dark caramel, toast crust, red wine, earthy, chocolate, acidic Ap: brown with maroon highlights, very light tan head, fair retention F: Much more acidic than the aroma would lead one to believe, tart, acetic acid, raspberry and cranberry, wine, caramel, light earthiness, hints of chocolate, toast crust, pomegranite, malt is more subdued behind acidity and fruit, lots of tart red fruit, dry finish, toasted oak, hints at roast M: warming/hot acid at end, light initial puckering, refreshing, low carbonation, med mouthfeel, light alcohol O: Slightly too acidic but very good, great aroma, has slightly more wild character than i see in RR sours, good complexities

Reddish brown color with a small head which quickly disappeared. Smells of sour cherries, raisins, oak, and vinegar. The taste has a little sweetness, but is quite sour with the sour cherries the most dominant flavor. The oak, vinegar, raisins, and perhaps some sour cranberries are also noticeable, with the oak leaving a bit of an aftertaste. Decent carbonation, light bodied, sour, and tart. This is a definite sipper due to the tartness, but it is well made. Worth trying again.

This product is extremely erratic. Sometimes it is phenomenal, sometimes it is so-so. This bottle was the latter. A: Reddish-brown, good clarity, pale tan head. S: Great: black cherry, acetic acid, currants, vanilla, a light spiciness, bordering on medicinal. No hop aroma, no diacetyl, a light wood aroma. T: Not as good as the aroma. A huge tannic bite, very astringent. Spiciness present, no hop character, fruitiness in the background, but difficult to find behind all the astringency. No diacetyl, wood flavor subtle, but present. Powerful sour with a decent background of malt sweetness. M: Medium bodied and carbonated. Both good. High astringency, strong acidity...NOT light on the palate. D: Great aroma, needs to be aged longer or blended. Too harsh at this stage.

had this brew courtesy of Bitch Face #2 Drink1121, poured into a duvel tulip a - dark brown with an amber hue when held up to the light s - vinegar, oak, rasin and some sour tartness t - vinegar, pretty sour, tastes like granny smith apples a sweet sour. Some darker fruits at work too maybe some rasins or plums m - light d - it is only 6% so its pretty good

Shared a bottle with kfsv034 the bitch face he is. A- Poured into Duvel tulip. Pours a dark crimson with asome slight head. Nothing special here, but looks like a Flanders. S- I get some really really sour apple here. Slight vinegar with some oak, but maily sour apple. T- Really really sour, almost mouth-puckering. A ton of green apple tart, little much for a Flanders IMO. M- Good carbonation, good thickness. D- Good ,but not great. Good beer, just too sour to have a few, even if its 6%

Pours an opaque dark chocolate brown with a fine-bubbled tan head. Aroma is strong, rich and fruity. Pleasantly sour flavor is strongly of sour apple and quite fierce - those who love sour ales should flip over this one! Texture is fairly smooth and nicely tingly.

On-tap at the Blue Palms Served into a tulip with one inch of tan head on top of a brown body. The nose was sour/tart with some cranberries. Some very faint sweetness as well. Definitely a sour, just shy of sucking on a lemon. Apples, tart cranberries and cherries, and some noticeable alcohol heat; somewhat acidic as well. The sour burst does dominate the taste a little too much. It almost feels like drinking a soda with all the fizz. Light on the tongue and medium/high carbonation. Burst of sour without any other key flavor players does hinder drinkability somewhat. Otherwise not a bad brew.

A - Dark brown with a slight crimson hue. Quarter inch of off-white to tan head with a little bit of lacing. S - Vinous with lots of black cherry and some hints of caramel sweetness. T - Definitely very tart up front but not overpoweringly sour. Lots of red wine character behind the sourness with some oak and again black cherry. Not much sweetness like some of the more common flanders reds I have access to. M - Moderate to high carbonation gives it a pleasant fizzy mouthfeel, but not overly so. D - Definitely on the tart side, but I can see myself finishing this 22oz bottle without much trouble. Not sure I'd go beyond that in a sitting though. Overall, this one is right on the money as far as reviews I've seen. Definitely an exceptional flanders red.

22oz bottle, poured into a standard pint glass. A: brown color, tan head, minimal lacing S: malty and a vinegar like sourness. T: tart, sour, almost puckers. it has a mild malty character, but is dominated by the sour. no hop character. MF: medium bodied, medium carbonation, sour and tart. Drinkability: very sour. very different. i want to drink more.

Unfortunately I just had the Consecration a couple of days ago which, although not the exact thing as this beer, is very similar. Brown, sour, etc. The one advantage of this over the Consecration is that the alcohol level is much more reasonable. Color is a pretty brown but the carbonation and head is a little disappointing. Flavor is a very good sour and dark fruit. Aroma is ok, could be more present; more sour without much else. In general a good beer, just not the best dark sour out there.

2007 Vintange courtest of Pokesbeerdude A: Murky brown with a puffy tan head that quickly rises then falls leaving a ring at the top of the bear that is constantly being replenished by the carbonations from the bottom of the glass S: Tart fruit notes of cherry and plenty of brett. Also quite a bit of wood and oak that adds some nice earthy quality T: Very much like the smell with the tart fruit coming through very nicely. I was very impressed by the wood notes. Some nice grape and almost a merlot like quality to this beer as it had some nice sweetness to go with the fruit. Also a bit like sangria M: Very dry and pretty mellow, slightly harsh due to the carbonation and a bit rubbery. D: A very accurate for the style and one that i would enjoy again without question but i dont think i could have a ton of this

Color: Deep dark brown. Short khaki head. Falls to a ring. Leaves lacing. Aroma: Sour cherry notes. Strong vinous quality . Some light woody/vanilla notes. Dark caramel round things out. Taste: Bracing sourness - Vinegar notes, w/ plenty of sour lime. Crisp granny smith apples notes blend in with the sour citrus notes. Sour cherries show up towards the end. The wood notes are light, leaving a hint of vanilla in the long lingering finish. Virtually no sweetness at all. Shows up a bit as things warm up to soften the sourness a touch. Finish is very dry w/ lingering citrus pith notes. Mouthfeel: Light end of medium bodied. Spritzy carbonation that fades over time. One tasty brew. The bracing sourness lends a definite refreshing quality. Not the best Flanders red ale to grace my palate, but a stellar brew nonetheless. This may be NB's best brew.

A: Poured a straw yellow color with a 1 finger head that quickly dissipated to nothing. No lacing. S: Faint aromas of grain, spiciness, honey, and citrus. T: Clean taste with grains and honey with a nice spiciness from the hops. M: Light mouthfeel with good carbonation D: Easily put a sixer down in the summer!

A relaxing summer ale with a soothing aroma of cereal grains accented with lemon-pepper. The color is a bright yet dense lemon-gold very showy and comes rimmed with a collar of white bubbles courtesy of its amply charged body. A simple, balanced beer with a long finish of flat English yeasts. Refreshing and serviceable.

The apparent lineage to brown ales is suggested in this brown porter emphasizing malt sweetness. The aroma is initially of potent molasses influence though of modest duration. The head also departs quickly, and the body is opaque burgundy-brown and void of carbonation. A tasty beer though lacking in vigor. Not to be confused with the robust, roasted porter style.

Had this at the Twisp brewpub and this was one their best beers. Dark , well headed and most definetly fullbodied. The chocolate notes really carried through into a fine finish. Very tasty and well crafted. The brewer also makes a great stout so order anything dark.

Had this on-tap at McGlinn's in Wenatchee on Memorial Day weekend for $3.50. Was a very dark brown, with a big, mocha colored head. Lots of lace. Smell was of dark, Colombian roast cofee and rich, dark chocolate. Smelled good! Taste was very similar to the smell. The roasty coffeeish aspect was up-front. It was quickly followed by, but never overwhelmed by, the chocolaty flavors. Not as complex tasting as some porters I've had, but everything a porter needs to be tasty was on hand. Moderately full-bodied porter. This wasn't particularly viscous or syrupy, but there was no mistaking it was a porter in the mouthfeel department. It had just the right level of carbonation. This was a very tasty porter, and functioned as an excellent dessert for my Philly Dip sandwich dinner.

I knew I was in trouble when this hefe brewed with local cherries arrived looking like a beer cocktail. The grayish, densely clouded ale showed a crimson blush like a Shirley Temple and came with not one, but two lemon wedges - both of which were promptly pressed into my water glass. Over-sized bubbles rose from the glass wall as I inhaled a smell like pink lemonade left in swamp. Seriously, the aroma was foul, especially after the lemons were dismissed from duty. This late summer seasonal has a mid-palate rush of cherry juice but no other virtues. Neither the hefe nor the cherries establish themselves with any authority and the union of the two doesn't pull together in any meaningful way.

A blind tasting of this beer could easily convince me that this is a chocolate stout brewed with real chocolate. It isn't. But the chocolate flavor is potent and convincing. The beer even appears turbid chocolate-brown colored as opposed to a more traditional stout-black. Chocolate malt character appears in the nose beside a more dominant mash tun graininess. They serve 'em cold at The Twisp. But let it warm and this undercarbonated oatmeal stout reveals an integrated hop spiciness late in the game. Non-traditional, but rich where you might like it to be.

Appearance is a light golden amber with a heafty head. Aroma is of light malts, slightly metallic. Taste carries a mild sweetness from the malts, grain and a cloying bitter metallic aftertaste. Mouthfeel is light to medium with good body. Not what I would consider a session, it doesn't have that clean finish I would consider in this type of beer to keep it going, so I'll just stop at this one.

Im at a partial loss to evaluate this Vienna-style lager as I really dont possess enough familiarity with the style to speak of it authoritatively. Its not widely reproduced in the Northwest and I cant say as Ive given the style much attention otherwise. Still, I know what I like and I know quality when I experience it, and my impression of Methows Vienna Lager was that it was rather middle-of-the-road. It offered slack carbonation and was nearly absent of suds. The grainy aroma was faint and the flavor was cereal essence tinged with sharp bittering. The body was also not especially clear for a lager and the taste was correspondingly not clean. Not entirely bad, but none too interesting either.

Appearance is a light golden with a thin head. Smell has a honey note with light malt and hops. Taste is quite sharp, not what I would consider to be in a cream ale, but not bad. It has a light to medium mouthfeel with good carbonation. It's not one for me to buy on a regular basis, I like bitter, but this leaves an aftertaste of slight metallic bitterness that sticks around.

Cream ales are gentle beers. Even so, this one is a little too timid. The hazed and pale, sunny yellow color is appealing though not especially consistent with the style, which generally emphasizes lager-like clarity. Likewise, the low CO2 and fleeting head are technical shortcomings. But I try to avoid rating to style and simply enjoy a beer for what it is. Methows Cream Ale is crisp, dry and almost tart though not abundantly flavorful. Not bad, but somewhat indistinct.

This is a really pale cream ale but the beer is really full bodied and easy drinking. I liked the hop hit but also the balance was dead on with a good malt aftertaste. This style is often overlooked by brewers but these guys did it justice. A good lighter offering that is food friendly.

This uber-IPA is over-hopped. Some people like over-hopped beers, especially IPAs. I understand the appeal, but only to a limited extent, beyond which a beer can quickly collapse into a state of imbalanced over-indulgence. Such is the case here. The bittering is simply too aggressive, creating an insurmountable obstacle to casual appreciation. The over-abundance of bittering-range hops delivers a smart sudsy head to the exceptionally dense orange-topaz body, though oddly there is very little hop aroma. Not unexpectedly, the mouthfeel is taut and suffers from the excess herbage. You might like this beer, but try a sample before committing to a pint. I might add that this was my second and final beer of the evening. I was tired enough for a variety of reasons, but Im convinced that all those hops made me ridiculously drowsy.

Has the appearance of hazed amber with a thin head. Smell is light sweet malt, citrus and hop. Taste has a malty sweetness with that touch of hop bite giving it the bitterness. Mouthfeel I would consider light to medium. I like the sweetness in the malt, but not having the clean finish I like, leaving for a bitter aftertaste.

pours gold with fluffy white head the nose reminds me of barossa shiraz. lots of spice and fruit, but the spice of aussies. it has a potent aroma of dessert spice, wild. the taste is more in line.. rich and full of fruit and cream with slilght tang. overall pleasant mouthfeel is lush and creamy. a treat of a sipper with well concealed alcohol. overall, it's very unique. the shiraz part threw me for a loop, but that aspect aside, really fun to drink.

Met up with Akorsak to get this beer. Thanks Adam! Of all the Scratch Series, this was the one I was most excited to try, and it did not disappoint. Pale body with a small head, almost no retention and no lacing. Smell is some bready malts with gin. Tasty beer. Sweet pale maltiness up front with some of what I believe is Juniper berry. Next, some nice peppery-coriander yeastiness. Through the finish some nice flavors tasting like (not overwhelming so) Gin. A little boozy in the finish though. Being a drinker of gin, I found this beer to be great. A good mouthfeel, slightly boozy. Extremely drinkable, especially considering the ABV. Great beer.

I believe this bottle is from DIM. Thank you. Pours a mostly clear golden color with an extremely short lived head. Smell is bright and herbal and lightly malty. I can definitely get the juniper berries from this. Taste is sweet and herbal again. A bit cloying, actually, and has kind of a spruce and mint like finish along with some yeastiness. A touch of alcohol shows, but couldn't tell it was over 10%. Gets harder and harder to drink still, despite the ABV being hidden well. Novelty beer...

12oz. bottle Pours a clear golden color with a small white head that fades. Mild lacing on the glass. Very bold and zesty aroma. Lots of bready and yeasty smells with a very spicy character. Bready and yeasty upfront followed by an aggressive bitter bite. Lots of spicy notes hit just before it finishes dry and boozy. Full body, medium carbonation. Misses the mark a bit, I think a little too aggressive for a tripel. It's also entirely possible that it's still young and not yet come of age. We will see how time treats this one. I am hopeful.

Received this brew from BeerTruth in a recent trade. I've had Scratch 1-7 and they've sorta been hit and miss so lets see what we get here. Drank from my Stone India Pale Ale tulip. Appearance- Pours a light straw yellow with a soft one finger white head that disappears fairly quickly leaving a spotty cap. A decently sized collar is left leaving tiny bits of spotty lacing. Smell- Very spicy and lightly floral nose that is apparent upon opening. Light ginger, coriander and I'm assuming the aroma that I can't place is the Yarrow Flower. Never had a beer with Yarrow in it (that I know of anyway). Malt is very present as well with a light honey sweetness and boozy finish. Taste- Very spicy from the start and that gin like influence is evident. The coriander is strong and there is a big berry presence that for some reason doesn't strike me as Juniper. Strong malty sweetness that is a little overbearing and plenty of yeast that is lightly dirty and funky. White pepper and clove are the majority of the spiciness around some light banana. Plenty of alcohol in the finish and although I think the spices are too much, I think the booziness really takes away from the beer more. A lingering banana and clove sweetness hangs around for quite some time. Mouthfeel- Thick and syrupy with a very cloying sweetness, plenty of zesty carbonation and loads of warming. Drinkability- Like I said earlier there is a bit to much spice and sweetness in this brew for my liking. They yeast is very Tripel but the rest of it is just too much for a enjoyable brew. I said these brews seem to be hit or miss and this one is a miss for me. Big thanks to Adam for the opportunity!

Appearance: hazy golden yellow in color with a short 1/2" head that lingered a bit. Smell: yeast with some big honey and fruit sweetness. Very pleasant on the nose. Taste: nice malt profile with honey, ripe berries, yeast, and some mild spiciness. Alcohol is noticeable and warming. Bitterness comes through nicely despite the sweetness. Mouthfeel: light prickliness at the start but smooth at the finish. Very long aftertaste as the flavors seem to linger in the mouth for quite a while. Medium-heavy bodied beer. Drinkability: the sweetness and alcohol levels make this a slow sipper, but enjoyable throughout the entire glass.

Poured into a Duvel tulip.. Cloudy golden appearance with very little head to speak of and virtually no lacing...appears rather thick.. Very nice aromas of that funky Belgian yeast, some sort of candied fruit (perhaps peach?), a faint hoppiness, and perhaps some brown sugar...I don't smell any booze at all.. Sweet candied fruits covered with brown sugar and maple syrup.... That's what I'm getting and its delicious...finishes a little spicy with some cinnamon or cloves, maybe even some nutmeg... Like a banana nut bread that's had a good brandy poured over it. Delicious... This was my first Scratch brew and I enjoyed the heck out of it.. It was sweet and delicious and a terrific sipper after dinner tonight..

Big thanks to DIM for throwing in this great extra. a - pour bright golden honey color, pretty cloudy, not much of a head at all s - big black pepper and coriander aromas, yeasty, what I'm assuming is some juniper berry, really spicy, light orange and hints of alcohol t - big fresh cracked black pepper up front along with a coriander-centric spiciness, some banana, orange, and (again, what I'm assuming is) juniper berry, big bready malt and yeast flavors on the finish with more coriander and other spice, a little alcohol heat m - medium-bodied, lots of prickly carbonation, slighly dry on the finish, some alcohol warming d - for a 10% abv beer, pretty drinkable, easy on the palate and interesting flavor Good tripel all around. I like the uniqueness of the juniper berry addition. Not quite as good as the Scratch #4 and #5, but well worth seeking out a bottle or two nonetheless.

Bottle courtesy of Miver: Poured a deep lightly hazy golden color ale with a small white foamy head with average retention and no lacing. Aroma of pear, juniper and bubble gum is quite intense but very enjoyable. Taste is a mix between a typical Belgian triple with some excellent notes of juniper, pear and bubblegum. Body is quite full with some average carbonation and no apparent alcohol. I really enjoyed this one even though the aroma and spicing is too intense to drink this regularly.

This was presented to me with about a finger's worth of solid, bone-white head with decent retention. The coriander was evident on the nose. The color was a cloudy lemon-yellow. The mouthfeel was medium with a very black-peppery taste on the tongue. The finish was dry and even a little hot. It was good, but one or two at a sitting would be plenty.

Appearance: Pours a hazy, pale yellow body with a thin, bubbly, white head. Smell: Pale malt aroma with notes of banana, spice, yeast, flowers, and yarrow. Ah, Yarrow, my old friend digs up an Allagash Fluxus flashback. Taste: Pale malts with a hit of sweet candi sugar. Splash of pear juice. Sour yeastiness. Hint of fresh, sliced bananas. Mild juniper berry character, but, then again, I've never had a beer infused with junper berries that really knocked me out of my seat with juniper flavor. I'm not really getting much hoppiness out of this thing. Lightly spicy and the distinct yarrow taste. A little peppery on the sweetish, yeasty finish. Mouthfeel: A hair above medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Drinkability: Another fun, fine experiment from the Tregs Scratch series, though I've never been particularly wild about additions of yarrow to beer.

The beer pours a hazy gold color with decent head retention and lacing. On the nose this beer is impressive. The gin/juniper berries is very apparent and couples nicely with the honey. The flavors on the palate replicate the nose, with juniper berries imparting almost a gingerale flavor with the honey. The beer has moderate sweetness, which once again plays nicely with the juniper. The beer actually seems fairly light on the palate, and it's hard to believe the abv. is 10%. The finish is long and smooth. Another excellent scratch beer from Troegs.

number1bum hooked me up with this brew. Scracth 3 was decent, let's see how this one matches up. 12 oz. bottle poured into a chalice. Pours a foggy bronzed straw yellow with a half finger white head that quickly dies down to just about nothing. Very minimal spots of lacing on the sides of the glass. Smell consists of evergreen, granny smith apples, clove, and pepper. Very unique aroma, but seems to work out fairly well. Some banana bread in the nose as well, but that seems to be a given for the style. For 10.1% abv, I can't seem to find any boozey scent, that's always good. Taste begins with pine and lime, uhhh, intereseting. Clove, corriander, and dry pepper on the tongue with a big burning alcohol in the back of the throat towards the end. The booze flavor really takes away from this beer. The spices seem to be over the top as well. Thick and chewy full body with that leaves an alcohol coating in the mouth. Carbonation is subtle. Scratch 3 is good, no need to try another stab at a Tripel. Most of the Scratch beers have been quite enjoyable, but this one falls very short. I'm looking forward to trying more in the series. Thanks again Josh, you were definitely right about this one.

This beer pours a cloudy pale orange color. The head is half an inch in height, and recedes rather quickly into minimal lacing. The aroma is of tangerine, orange, barnyard, and anise. The taste is funkier than the aroma with the barnyard yeast flavors up front. It is followed by citrus fruits with a hot alcohol presence in the finish. The mouthfeel is medium-full bodied with lively carbonation. Overall, this is a very good American version of a Tripel. I would love to drink this again.

Pours a hazy apricot gold color with thin white head, little retention and almost non-existent lacing. Smells of apples, peppery spices, coriander, clove, citrus, banana, biscuits, and alcohol. Tastes of green apples with a lemony tartness followed by a sweet honey and wheat middle and clove and candied banana in the finish along with a firm alcohol presence. Medium full in body and low in carbonation, but does offer a nice tingle. Spicy, sweet, and alcoholic. A good tripel, but is really powerful, definitely a sipper.

Wow, I've had this beer cellaring for about two months now and it is not what i expected. Poured a deep, dark, almost opaque brown with very little head and almost no lacing. Smells sweet, and fruity caramel notes. Again, i get the caramel taste, and fruit, most notably dark cherries and some rich apples. I dont really taste the high ABV, other than the alcohol sweetness. Not the best I've had from Unibroue by far, but clearly satisfying.

***Corked Bottle*** A - Looks like Black Cherry Soda but a little thicker and has a thin and non-lasting head. S- Dark Fruit soaked in alcohol. Mildly sweet. T- A bit sweet. A bit spicey. A tiny bit of nuts and apricot in the middle of all that alcohol soaked dark fruitiness. M - This is a pretty full bodied beer. The low hop and low carbonation leave a long lingering array of flavors. D - Big beers are never as drinkable to me. I tend to like them more but drink them less. At 10+% and a very tongue engrossing flavor this is a nice bottle to share once in a while, not an everyday kind of thing.

A- Very dark with a tan heads that fades to a lasting ring. S- Dark fruits (prune, raisins) with notes of tobacco and alcohol. T- Very malty backbone with notes of dark fruit being most prominent. Some rock sugar seems to be present as well. There is a pleasant warming sensation from the alcohol and a dryish finish. M- Full body with a fairly low carbonation. D- Pretty straightforward in its malty sweetness. The dark fruit taste/aroma bring some complexity but it's just a little to simple for what I was expecting.

Best Before Jan 30, 2016. Beer is black. Faint reddish hints are observable on the edges. A beige head of moderate size results from a vigorous pour, starts to recede fairly quickly. Smell is quite fruity- cherry, raisin. Toffee or caramel is present as well, slightly reminiscent of a caramel apple. Brown sugar. Faint cocoa scents and some Belgian yeast. Good smell. Not as strong as I would have expected. Taste is a bit of a surprise. Fruit flavours are lighter than expected (in flavour, not intensity). I can taste strawberry pretty clearly along with the raisin and plum flavours that are more expected. A bit of a bubble-gum flavour as well. Caramel flavour is present and very nice. Alcohol is incredibly well hidden- only a slight bit of heat. A little bit of spice. Excellent. Mouthfeel is very good. Moderate to low carbonation level, very smooth. Nice full body. Overall, just an excellent beer.

Review from notes. A: Pours a dark brown color with ruby highlights when held up to the light. Decent sized tan head, moderate retention and sporadic lacing. S: A little dark fruit - grapes and currant, some molasses, and a lot of Belgian spice, mostly cloves. T: Sweet dark fruit up from, grapes and prune, some more molasses, and some pepper and clove spice. M: Medium to full bodied with light carbonation. Sweeter than expected with a slightly dry finish. O: A pretty good beer, not I would expect otherwise from Unibroue. While I liked it, I probably wouldn't grab it again. Might be the style as most Belgian Strong Dark Ales don't grab me.

Pours a very dark brown that is almost opaque. Red edges show when held to the light. There is an inch of cream colored head. Spotty lacing. Then nose is bringing up a lot of dark fruits including cherries, plum, date, and a bit of apple. There is some caramel intertwined and there is a sweet biscuit-like malt involved as well. The taste has a nice subtle sweetness that melds all of the above fruit flavors together creating a nice treat. A cherry taste is mainly notice but there are also some plum and fig notes. The bread-like malt is noticed in the finish along with just a tad of caramel and clove. Then mouthfeel is syrupy and comfortably textured. The viscosity of this brew keeps the aftertastes flowing. Enjoyable. Overall, I think is a great Belgian Strong Dark Ale and the sweet characteristics are enjoyable without a cloying feel. Very nice.

Poured in to Duvel tulip. A - Poured a murky dark brown and settled almost black with two fingers of bubbly light brown head that slowly receded. S - Intense dark fruit up front - raisins, plums and figs. Dark caramel and toffee round out the nose. Some light Belgian yeast aroma in the background that was much more subtle than I expected. T - Raisins, figs, dark fruit up front. The background has caramel, toffee, Belgian yeast, a touch of chocolate and spice. very robust and complex. M - Medium body with a nice chew. Moderate carbonation. O - This was an excellent beer. I wish I could get this locally to I could stock up the cellar.

750ml corked and caged bottle. Best before 01-30-2016. It pours a deep blackish brown with a nice-looking whiteish/tan head. The nose is loaded with yeast scents. Some dark fruit and spice and even a hint of bubble gum. Big strawberry and a hint of cocoa in the aroma too. It is pretty odd. The aroma has the flavor of sweet fruits and some dark fruit. There is a bit of clove and just a hint of cocoa. It is pretty good, but not outstanding.

Pours dark brown with a big cream-colored head. Some retention, some lacing. Very pretty. Big belgian yeast and toasted malt aroma. Brown sugar, fruit, brown bread, some spice, some light cocoa and bruised fruit. Big alcohol that leads to a dried out bitterness. Complex and delicious. Fuller bodied, moderate carbonation. An easy drinker, and dangerous at 10.5%. Very worth trying. I like that this can be sipped over time and thoroughly enjoyed without being completely in the tank from the booze. Another winner from this brewer.

Pours a dark brown with crimson highlights if held to the light. Beautiful coffee colored two finger head, which sticks around a bit, and slowly disappears to a sliver. Fig, clove, apple, and toast are what I pick up on the nose. It's not as complex as some of the best in this style (Belgians), but it's still very well done. The taste is nice- although pretty dry for my taste. The fruits, spices, toast all come through- but the beer is so dry they evaporate off my tastebuds and there's only a mild aftertaste left. None of the 10.5% alcohol is felt or noticed. Feel is a little thin and dry for what the best in this style brings. The flavor has potential, it just never really gets to open up IMO... Overall, a very good beer- but not quite up to the Rochefort 8's, Cuvee de Kaiser Blau on the style list. Still, this is a totally solid brew, and just a few minor changes away from straight 4.5's. I enjoyed drinking it- Cheers!

on tap in a goblet A-tap was a dark brown color with a tan head very nice lacing on glass S is dark fruit first with raisins and prune smells and a nice yeast smell T- prunes and dark fruit,pepper, bready yeast,sweet caramel malts a touch of molasses,grape and wine like qualities very nice M- very tart and crisp with high carbonation O- a tart and carbonated dark ale with champagne and wine like tastes it a great brew

Nice surprise to find this on draft locally, and at $4 a chalice it's a hell of a value. Plum and grapes, toffee and a dusting of cocoa powder. Bit of old earthiness adds depth and alcohol is as tame as a lot of beers of less strength. Yeast throws off a little black pepper and clove. Not as impressive as the bottled version, but Unibroue does dark Belgian ales right.

A-Pours a somewhere between darkest possible brown and coal black that holds up a sturdy,very Belgian,almost grey crown that showed good retention and left stringy,gummy strands of lacing. S-Dark cherry,chickory,cardamom,clove,brown sugar,yeast rolls and Fig newtons. T-Rich,dark fruit flavors of plum,date and red currant with caramelized sugars,black pepper,bready yeast and dry spice. M-Medium/full mouthfeel with a good balance between sweetness and earthy spice but a slightly fleeting finish.Moderate carbonation. O-A good beer that did not disappoint.

S: Dark and rich. Primarily raisins and malt, with a nice, low-key sweetness - like bread pudding made with with raisins and brandy. T: Mmmm...mild coffee up front under dominating carbonation that turns prickly halfway through until it dissolves into a powerful, thick, sticky, slightly bitter molasses/coffee flavor. Finishes like a stout - with a similar complex bitterness.

Pours very dark brown with orange tint. Big carmel/toffee nose. Big flavors; gigantic flavor of cooked fruit and apricots with black coffee and sweet malt. Finish is medium/short and stops this from being cloyingly sweet. Soda pop character but good. Layered flavors of sweet malt, figs, prunes, raisins and brown sugar but with hints of cola and with a Dr. Pepper flavored finish. Different but nice.

GLASS: Snifter TEMP: Cellared @ approx 45 degrees Pours a super dark brown color, almost black. Almost two-fingers of tan foam of medium density form the head. Retention is pretty good. Lacing is sporadic and fairly sticky. Dark fruits and brown sugars hit me first. Light phenols. Nice yeastiness. Good spice notes. Not quite the big nose that I was expecting. Again, this one is pretty subdued, which is not what was expected. Good malty backbone, with a fairly big yeastiness coming over the top of it. Nice spice notes. Mild notes of figs and dark fruits. Light touch of brown sugar. Not very complex, but a tasty brew, nonetheless. Almost full-bodied. Most of my enjoyment was killed by the high level of carbonation. It really gets in the way of everything else. It's just all sharp and fizzy, in the mouth, and completely detracts from this beer. While the high abv is nicely masked, the carbonation really kills the enjoyment level of this one for me.
